p: Medicinal plants offer a set of phytochemicals that have potential for microbial disease control; this is due to the spectrum of secondary metabolites present in extracts, which include phenolic compounds, quinones, flavonoids, alkaloids, terpenoids, and polyacetylenes [ 4, 5]. For example, cis-cis-p-Menthenolide, extracted from Mentha suaveolens ssp . insularis, acts as an inhibitor of violacein production ( Chromobacterium violaceum) and biofilm formation [ 6]; similar effects have been found for Terpinen-4-ol ( Melaleuca alternifolia essential oil) [ 7], Carum copticum essential oil and phenols [ 8], d-limonene nanoemulsion on Escherichia coli [ 9], Salvadora persica L. and Astilbe rivularis, Fragaria nubicola, and Osbeckia nepalensis [ 10] methanolic extracts, and other medicinal plants [ 11].
